P1.Explanation: The Sicilian defence is a half-opening, meaning it opens with e4 but dose not follow with e5. Black commonly plays c5.

P2.Explanation: Its common for white to counter with f4, so we play pawn d6 in defense.

P3.Explanation: White would commonly play pawn to d4, in which black would take it with its pawn on c5.

P4.Explanation: White recaptures the d4 square with the knight. Black develops the knight to f6, aiming to complete their development and prepare for kingside action.

P5.Explanation: White develops the second knight to c3, supporting the center and preparing for kingside castling. Black plays d6 to strengthen the position and prepare for castling.

P6.Explanation: Black will play pawn to g6, then white will bring the bishop from c1 to e3

P7.Explanation: At this point, we can see the board is almost completely developed. The only issue is castling.

P8.Explanation: Black moves the bishop to g7 and white moves the pawn to f3.

P9.Explanation: Black moves to c6, followed by white's queen to d2, then black castles king side. This was the Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defense. We will cover the other variations in upcomning lessons.
